definition: Land used for growing crops or farming activities

positive_examples: The farmer planted wheat across 200 acres of fertile farmland
Irrigation systems watered the vegetable fields during the drought
The orchard produced apples and pears on terraced hillsides
Rice paddies stretched across the valley floor
The vineyard covered the gentle slopes with rows of grapevines
Corn grew tall in the cultivated fields behind the barn
negative_examples: Cattle grazed peacefully in the open pasture
The hiking trail wound through the forest preserve
Wild flowers bloomed in the untouched meadow
The parking lot was paved with asphalt
Residential houses lined the suburban street
The golf course had perfectly manicured grass
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Pasture, Forest, UrbanLand, Wilderness, RecreationalLand

opposite_reasoning: UrbanArea provides the strongest complementary opposition to AgriculturalLand. Both are major land-use classifications that are largely mutually exclusive in geographic planning contexts. The rural-agricultural vs. urban-developed distinction captures meaningful semantic dimensions: natural/cultivated vs. built environment, food production vs. human habitation/commerce, low-density vs. high-density. This opposition has high availability in both WordNet and SUMO ontologies, and provides clear conceptual distance for Fisher-LDA axes. While not directly relevant to deception detection, it offers robust semantic separation for general concept steering.
